snippet.textDisplay: I have naturally straight hair, nearly all my life I have curled it every morning filled it full of products and sprays. Finally now I’m 30 this year, I have used a curler only once in 2 years, I accept it because I am thankful how easy it is to manage! I love curls though, I’ll always wish I had volume and curls lol.
snippet.textOriginal: I have naturally straight hair, nearly all my life I have curled it every morning filled it full of products and sprays. Finally now I’m 30 this year, I have used a curler only once in 2 years, I accept it because I am thankful how easy it is to manage! I love curls though, I’ll always wish I had volume and curls lol.

snippet.textDisplay: @BradMondo for the first video that look is totally achievable without the relaxer, it just isn’t permanent.
snippet.textOriginal: @BradMondo for the first video that look is totally achievable without the relaxer, it just isn’t permanent.

snippet.textDisplay:
The second girl made me nervous.

DO NOT wash and blow dry your hair before a relaxer. The least amount of manipulation, the better. In fact you want at least 2-3 days of low manipulation before the relaxer application.

DO NOT scratch your scalp 2-3 days before application. Tears or scratches to the scalp are the kiss of death

DO plan where/how/timing of the relaxer application before you go in. Have a full plan to achieve a consistent result for all of your hair. Key to a consistent result is knowing the various textures in your hair and which areas will require more/less time to process.

DO apply a protective barrier to your edges and ears. Vaseline will do. Best would be a protective product designed to work with the relaxer. If you use Vaseline or some other base, don’t cover areas your want to relax since the base will act as a barrier and lessen the efficacy of the relaxer

DO detangle and separate your hair into at least 4 sections to apply. Be gentle.

DO leave about 1/4 inch to the roots for the last phase of application

DO part and apply the relaxer in smaller sections (apply downward. Let the hair lay flat) and work quickly. Don’t slather it in with your hands like a moisturizer. A brush applicator is best. You can use a narrow toothed comb if you know what you’re doing. You may need to do some light combing to ensure the product is applied to tangle free hair (very important).

DO get the product applied to all of the hair before you start working the product in.

DO finish out the root application then fully work the product in again

DO pay attention to timing and monitor your hair while the relaxer is processing. You can look at your hair and see the texture change with the product in it. Stay keen to when you see you hair reaching the desired result and keep watch on the clock. This dual diligence is important. You don’t want to over process your hair.

DO thoroughly rinse out all of the product and quickly apply the neutralizer wash. If you experience a burning sensation before you achieve the desired result, rinse the product out right away (still apply the neutralizer. Always neutralize whenever you have relaxer in your hair for any length of time).

DO give the hair a good deep conditioning or an otherwise moisture restorative process.

DO keep the hair moisturized post application and styling. Oil moisturizers, sprays or some other daily moisture routine will help your hair stay healthy and avoid breakage. Try to stay away from products with drying alcohols.

DO minimize heat styling

DO have a head covering or pillow covers that are kind to the hair. Silk or satin bonnets and pillow covers

DO minimize exposure to the elements ongoing

DO have a reasonable “touch up” routine. A “touch up” is when you go in and relax new growth so that is is consistent with the rest of your already relaxed hair. This is a balance - you don’t want to wait too long or the hair will start to break due to the 2 textures. You also want to ensure you have enough new growth for a touch up and that you aren’t double processing the same hair (applying product to already relaxed hair). Only apply relaxer to the new growth. 1/4 inch or more is usually safe

DO go to a professional. DIYing this process can be dangerous. Don’t try this at home until you have some education and experience under your belt.
snippet.textOriginal:
The second girl made me nervous.  

DO NOT wash and blow dry your hair before a relaxer.  The least amount of manipulation, the better.  In fact you want at least 2-3 days of low manipulation before the relaxer application. 

DO NOT scratch your scalp  2-3 days before application. Tears or scratches to the scalp are the kiss of death 

DO plan where/how/timing of the relaxer application before you go in. Have a full plan to achieve a consistent result for all of your hair. Key to a consistent result is knowing the various textures in your hair and which areas will require more/less time to process. 

DO apply a protective barrier to your edges and ears. Vaseline will do. Best would be a protective product designed to work with the relaxer.  If you use Vaseline or some other base, don’t cover areas your want to relax since the base will act  as a barrier and lessen the efficacy of the relaxer 

DO detangle and separate your hair into at least 4 sections to apply. Be gentle. 

DO leave about 1/4 inch to the roots for the last phase of application 

DO part and apply the relaxer in smaller sections (apply downward.  Let the hair lay flat) and work quickly. Don’t slather it in with your hands like a moisturizer. A brush applicator is best.  You can use a narrow toothed comb if you know what you’re doing. You may need to do some light combing to ensure the product is applied to tangle free hair (very important). 

DO get the product applied to all of the hair before you start working the product in. 

DO finish out the root application then fully work the product in again 

DO pay attention to timing and monitor your hair while the relaxer is processing.  You can look at your hair and see the texture change with the product in it. Stay keen to when you see you hair reaching the desired result and keep watch on the clock.  This dual diligence is important.  You don’t want to over process your hair.

DO thoroughly rinse out all of the product and quickly apply the neutralizer wash.  If you experience a burning sensation before you achieve the desired result, rinse the product out right away (still apply the neutralizer.  Always neutralize whenever you have relaxer in your hair for any length of time). 

DO give the hair a good deep conditioning or an otherwise moisture restorative process. 

DO keep the hair moisturized post application and styling. Oil moisturizers, sprays or some other daily moisture routine will help your hair stay healthy and avoid breakage. Try to stay away from products with drying alcohols. 

DO minimize heat styling 

DO have a head covering or pillow covers that are kind to the hair.  Silk or satin bonnets and pillow covers 

DO minimize exposure to the elements ongoing

DO have a reasonable “touch up” routine.  A “touch up” is when you go in and relax new growth so that is is consistent with the rest of your already relaxed hair. This is a balance  - you don’t want to wait too long or the hair will start to break due to the 2 textures.  You also want to ensure you have enough new growth for a touch up and that you aren’t double processing the same hair (applying product to already relaxed hair). Only apply relaxer to the new growth. 1/4 inch or more is usually safe

DO go to a professional. DIYing this process can be dangerous. Don’t try this at home until you have some education and experience under your belt.

snippet.textDisplay: I had a relaxer since I was a teen. I stopped using one when I lost my job and i had to cut expenses...once I figured out how to take care of my natural hair my hair was so much healthier. Then I thought about how they don't regulate the chemicals in these relaxers. More power to those that want to continue but not me baaaybeeee

snippet.textDisplay: Question! I have super fine, super thin hair and for my job I’m required to wear it back constantly and through High School I wore it up in a pony or in a bun. So basically my whole life it’s been up. I didn’t start noticing it until recently but my hair line is starting to move farther and farther back and I don’t want to go bald! So I need some tips to help my hair like grow back and to prevent further thining out and balding. Help!! Thanks for any tips!
snippet.textOriginal: Question! I have super fine, super thin hair and for my job I’m required to wear it back constantly and through High School I wore it up in a pony or in a bun. So basically my whole life it’s been up. I didn’t start noticing it until recently but my hair line is starting to move farther and farther back and I don’t want to go bald! So I need some tips to help my hair like grow back and to prevent further thining out and balding. Help!! Thanks for any tips!

snippet.textDisplay: BRAD PLEASE HELP! Does purple shampoo work on hair that is NOT colored but with age my hair has gone from platinum blonde as a child and just darkened throughout the years. It's blonde but has A LOT OF RED IN IT!! I've only ever used temporary color, 29 washes and it's pretty much blonde.i have always used the same color as my own hair.  I don't have grey hair I have white hair that actually looks very shiny and pretty when i color it. But I HATE how it's turning red, just like mom and the few other blondes in my family. Please advise ✌🏼💜
snippet.textOriginal: BRAD PLEASE HELP! Does purple shampoo work on hair that is NOT colored but with age my hair has gone from platinum blonde as a child and just darkened throughout the years. snippet.textDisplay: My stylist kinda forced me to get my hair relaxed just a month after I bleached it (which I later learned that it’s a big ass No No) 3 hours later my hair started burning and clumping really bad, he said that he’ll give me a trim and that I was going to be fine (take in mind I payed 150 dollars 3000 pesos for it and they used me to practice without me consenting)  a few weeks later It got worse and I had to shave my head cause I had balls of burned hair on the back and top of my head .... It’s been a year and a half and I haven’t been able to grow it that much (not even shoulder length) cause my scalped got 2 degree burns and now with (the little amount of length I have) I have anxiety every time anyone touches my hair or when I comb it ... I have nightmares about that day.
snippet.textOriginal: My stylist kinda forced me to get my hair relaxed just a month after I bleached it (which I later learned that it’s a big ass No No) 3 hours later my hair started burning and clumping really bad, he said that he’ll give me a trim and that I was going to be fine (take in mind I payed 150 dollars 3000 pesos for it and they used me to practice without me consenting)  a few weeks later It got worse and I had to shave my head cause I had balls of burned hair on the back and top of my head .... It’s been a year and a half and I haven’t been able to grow it that much (not even shoulder length) cause my scalped got 2 degree burns and now with (the little amount of length I have) I have anxiety every time anyone touches my hair or when I comb it ... snippet.textDisplay: Growing up I always had a relaxer since I was a kid (just for me lol). I did not have a choice in what my mom did to my hair. When I hit college that’s when I learned about relaxers and the harmful stuff so I asked my mom if she can chop off all my relaxed hair and she did at that time I was doing my own hair anyways. Fast forward to a few years later my hair was shoulder length and CURLY I had no idea I had very curly hair! And I love it till this day! I also have fine hair so it straightens pretty easy but I wish my mom knew better back then. Definitely not relaxing my kids’ hair!
snippet.textOriginal: Growing up I always had a relaxer since I was a kid (just for me lol). I did not have a choice in what my mom did to my hair. When I hit college that’s when I learned about relaxers and the harmful stuff so I asked my mom if she can chop off all my relaxed hair and she did at that time I was doing my own hair anyways. I also have fine hair so it straightens pretty easy but I wish my mom knew better back then. Definitely not relaxing my kids’ hair!

snippet.textDisplay: I love that you don't judge our hair care methods, thank you. I did the big chop to natural 10 months ago. One thing i forgot is my hirsutism so my now shoulder length hair (stretched) takes 2 hours to style and I am now suffering from tendonitis. I am now going to wig it for most of the time and save my real hair for special occasions.
snippet.textOriginal: I love that you don't judge our hair care methods, thank you. I did the big chop to natural 10 months ago. snippet.textDisplay: Can you relax your hair into less-curly hair? Like curls you would get with a curling iron for example? It's still a lot more maintenance than straight hair but for people with the time and patience it could be super cool I guess

snippet.textDisplay: Relaxers permanently break really important bonds in the hair causing it to dry out and become too  porous to retain moisture,  hence perpetual dryness and breakage. This significantly lessens the chance of length retention. That's why for many years people thought black people couldn't grow long hair (Not including those naturals with long hair that shrinks and looks short). It also causes  damage to the scalp, this hinders growth because it damages the follicles. There's also a host of health related issues that it's been linked to.  I wish it was never invented. They look "pretty" though
snippet.textOriginal: Relaxers permanently break really important bonds in the hair causing it to dry out and become too  porous to retain moisture,  hence perpetual dryness and breakage. This significantly lessens the chance of length retention. That's why for many years people thought black people couldn't grow long hair (Not including those naturals with long hair that shrinks and looks short). It also causes  damage to the scalp, this hinders growth because it damages the follicles. There's also a host of health related issues that it's been linked to.  I wish it was never invented. They look "pretty" though

snippet.textDisplay: This reminds me of when I bought a jet black hair dye and it said it had a relaxer in it and me, being a 13 year old white boy, I had no idea what that was. I always read the boxes now and buy my stuff from the beauty supply store.

snippet.textDisplay: as someone who knows a bit about relaxers, never ever , ever comb a relaxer through. the hair is already fragile and combing it through could break off the hair. all it needs is to be smoothed with the back of the comb, don't comb, ok that is all.

snippet.textDisplay:
So I got my first relaxer at 14 yrs old. I’ll be 50 this year. Yes, there was an addiction to the creamy crack. Not to brag but my hair was gorgeous and thick all these years.

But ... March ‘19 I went to get my regular relaxer and it would NOT straighten. In fact it just waved (not napped) back up. Why? Hormonal changes aka Menopause. So I wash, deep condition and blow dry and flat iron or wear it curly for a couple of days (I look wretched in curls).

Not sure if it was my grade of hair or only having four stylists over that period of time or if it was a miracle from above, but my hair was never damaged or fell out. 🤷🏾‍♀️ The chemicals were good to me.
snippet.textOriginal:
So I got my first relaxer at 14 yrs old. I’ll be 50 this year. Yes, there was an addiction to the creamy crack. Not to brag but my hair was gorgeous and thick all these years. 

But ... March ‘19 I went to get my regular relaxer and it would NOT straighten. In fact it just waved (not napped) back up. Why? Hormonal changes aka Menopause. So I wash, deep condition and blow dry and flat iron or wear it curly for a couple of days (I look wretched in curls). 

Not sure if it was my grade of hair or only having four stylists over that period of time or if it was a miracle from above, but my hair was never damaged or fell out. 🤷🏾‍♀️ The chemicals were good to me.

snippet.textDisplay: OML Brad looks SO HANDSOME with dark hair 😍 I’m also so glad he’s as amazed by relaxing as I am 😂 I’m in beauty school right now and relaxing is so satisfying. Brad should be a teacher he’s so good at explaining how things work!
